questions.text: Which of the following is not ligated for the control of epistaxis?(AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Internal carotid artery

 

Internal carotid artery is not ligated in epistaxis control due to high percentage of cerebral complications and high mortality.

 

Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control:

 

  • Trans nasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine artery - TESPAL
  • If not controlled, maxillary artery ligation
  • If still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation
  • In case, the bleeding site is superior to the level of middle turbinate, then anterior and posterior ethmoidal vessels should be ligated.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal artery: This artery may be ligated if the bleeding site is superior to the level of the middle turbinate, as it is one of the contributing vessels to the nasal cavity that might be involved in epistaxis.

 

Option C. Maxillary artery: Ligation of the maxillary artery is considered if epistaxis is not controlled by less invasive methods such as the ligation of the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Option D. External carotid artery: As a last resort, if bleeding persists despite ligation of more specific branches, ligation of the external carotid artery may be performed to control severe epistaxis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of severe epistaxis, it is critical to understand the hierarchy of arterial ligation, starting with the least risky options. The internal carotid artery should never be ligated due to its vital role in cerebral blood supply, highlighting the importance of targeted vascular control in surgical interventions to minimize complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with nonaxial proptosis of the left eye. The patient gives a history of a road traffic accident 15 years back. The CT image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Frontal mucocele

 

The given clinical scenario and the image findings are suggestive of a frontal mucocele.

 

A frontal mucocele is a benign cystic lesion that develops in the frontal sinus, which is one of the air-filled spaces located in the forehead region of the skull. It typically occurs as a result of the blockage or obstruction of the frontal sinus drainage pathway, leading to the accumulation of mucus within the sinus cavity. Over time, the trapped mucus can cause the sinus walls to expand, forming a mucocele.

 

 

Patient presents with headache, diplopia, and proptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontal meningiomas: originates from the meninges, benign brain tumors presenting with headaches, seizures, vomiting, personality changes, and cognitive impairment. Given below is a Coronal MRI section.

 

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: is the most common benign tumor of nasopharynx. Patients present with profuse epistaxis and nasal obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Pseudotumor of the orbit: is an idiopathic inflammation of the orbit presenting with painful proptosis, diplopia, and orbital congestion. Imaging shows right medial rectus muscle which is diffusely enlarged with moderate homogeneous enhancement with relative involvement of its tendinous insertion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Frontal mucoceles are a significant cause of proptosis and orbital symptoms, particularly following a history of facial trauma or sinus disease. Prompt diagnosis and surgical intervention to decompress the sinus and restore drainage can prevent complications and relieve symptoms.

choices.text: Making him sit in front row in class

questions.text: A child has bilateral SNHL. Which of the following is not preferred in the child?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This procedure is primarily used to treat chronic adenoiditis and otitis media with effusion (OME), which are associated with conductive hearing loss (CHL), not SNHL. Since the child has SNHL, this treatment is not appropriate.

 

Other Options:

 

Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) indicates that there is a problem in the inner ear (cochlea) or the auditory nerve. When treating bilateral SNHL in a child, certain interventions are preferred based on the underlying pathology and the severity of the hearing loss.

 

Option A. Cochlear Implant: This is a viable option for children with severe to profound SNHL where the cochlea is affected but the auditory nerve is intact. The implant bypasses the damaged cochlea and directly stimulates the auditory nerve, allowing the child to hear.

 

Option C. Making him sit in front row in class: This is a common accommodation to help children with hearing loss to better hear and engage in classroom activities. It minimizes the distance between the child and the teacher, thus reducing the impact of hearing loss.

 

Option D.  Hearing Aid: This is suitable for children with mild to moderate SNHL. Hearing aids amplify sounds, making them louder and easier to hear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is not preferred for treating bilateral sensorineural hearing loss as it addresses conditions causing conductive hearing loss, not sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man from a coastal region presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of recurrent nosebleeds, nasal obstruction, and a fleshy, polypoidal growth in his nasal cavity that appears pink to purple and bleeds easily on touch. He reports frequent swimming in local ponds, and his symptoms have progressively worsened over the past few months. A biopsy of the lesion reveals sporangia with bursting spores. Based on the clinical presentation and biopsy findings, Rhinosporidium seeberi is identified as the causative organism. Which of the following categories does Rhinosporidium seeberi belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Protistan protozoa

 

Rhinosporidium seeberi, the causative organism of rhinosporidiosis, was historically considered a fungus but is now classified as an aquatic Protistan protozoa. The life cycle of Rhinosporidium seeberi involves trophic, sporangium formation, and endospore production stages, contributing to its ability to cause mucosal polypoidal growths, particularly in the nasal cavity. The infection typically occurs through exposure to contaminated water, often in endemic coastal areas, and presents with characteristic strawberry-like lesions that bleed easily. Diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, revealing sporangia with bursting spores, and treatment involves surgical excision with cauterization.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Fungal organism: Although previously thought to be a fungus, Rhinosporidium seeberi has been reclassified based on genetic and structural studies, differentiating it from true fungal pathogens.

 

Option C. Bacterial pathogen: Bacteria cause a wide range of infections, but they are structurally distinct from the sporangia-producing nature of Rhinosporidium seeberi, which does not fit bacterial classification.

 

Option D. Viral agent: Viruses are acellular pathogens that replicate within host cells and do not produce the sporangia or polypoidal masses seen with Rhinosporidium seeberi, making this classification incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:


Rhinosporidium seeberi, responsible for rhinosporidiosis, is classified as a Protistan protozoa, highlighting the importance of accurate organism classification in diagnosing and managing infections. It presents with characteristic bleeding polypoidal masses in the nasal cavity and is commonly acquired through exposure to contaminated water in endemic areas.

questions.text: A post-COVID patient, who is a known diabetic, develops unilateral facial pain and loosening of teeth. Which investigation would you do to confirm the diagnosis on this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biopsy with histopathologic examination

 

The given scenario of a post-COVID diabetic patient with facial pain and loosening of teeth is suggestive of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. Among the given options, Biopsy with histopathologic examination would be the investigation for definitive diagnosis on this patient.

 

The primary reason that appears to be facilitating Mucorales spores to germinate in people with COVID-19 is

 

  1.  An ideal environment of low oxygen (hypoxia)
  2. high glucose (diabetes, new-onset hyperglycemia, steroid-induced hyperglycemia)
  3. Acidic medium (metabolic acidosis, diabetic ketoacidosis [DKA])
  4. High iron levels (increased ferritins)
  5. Decreased phagocytic activity of white blood cells (WBC) due to immunosuppression (SARS-CoV-2 mediated, steroid-mediated or background comorbidities) coupled with several other shared risk factors including prolonged hospitalization with or without mechanical ventilators

 

Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is the most common form of mucormycosis. It commonly occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus.

 

The presenting features are facial pain, numbness, loosening of teeth, conjunctival swelling, congestion, and blurry vision. When the disease spreads to the orbit, proptosis can be present. Due to invasion of the blood vessels, mucor fungus causes ischemic necrosis presenting as a black eschar, involving inferior turbinate, palate or the sinus. It can later spread to the frontal lobe of the brain and cavernous sinus.

 

 

 

Confirmation of diagnosis is by biopsy and histopathologic examination which shows aseptate fungi with thick-walled, ribbon-like, hyphae branching at right angles.

 

 

MRI is more sensitive to detecting orbital and nervous involvement than CT.

 

Contrast-enhanced MRI is the imaging technique of choice – black turbinate sign is seen

 

 

Post-contrast T1-weighted coronal MR image shows non enhancing soft tissue, “black turbinate sign,” within the left maxillary sinus (asterisk). The mucosa of the inferior turbinate and a portion of the left middle turbinate demonstrate focal lack of the enhancement (arrowheads).

 

Management

 

  • Antifungal therapy with Amphotericin B
  •  Surgical debridement of the affected tissues.
  •  Treatment of underlying cause
  • Control of blood sugars in diabetic patients

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): Useful for assessing the extent of disease, especially in identifying orbital and central nervous system involvement. It provides detailed images that help in planning the extent of surgical debridement.

 

Option C. Serum Ferritin: Elevated ferritin levels are commonly seen in mucormycosis due to the fungus’s use of iron from the host, which aids its growth. While not diagnostic, high ferritin levels can support the suspicion of mucormycosis in the right clinical context.

 

Option D. HbA1c (Glycated Hemoglobin): This test reflects long-term glucose control and is crucial in managing diabetic patients. Although it does not diagnose mucormycosis, poor glycemic control indicated by a high HbA1c value is a risk factor for the development of fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are critical for patients suspected of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, especially in those with risk factors like diabetes and a recent COVID-19 infection. A biopsy with histopathologic examination is essential for confirming the diagnosis. This condition requires a multidisciplinary approach involving antifungal therapy, surgical debridement, and meticulous management of underlying conditions like diabetes to prevent serious complications and improve outcomes.

questions.text:
Organize the subsequent structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors and moving towards the cortex: (INICET May 2023)

 

  1. Auditory Cortex
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Cochlear Nucleus
  4. Lateral leminiscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Olivary complex
  7. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-3-6-4-5-7-1

 

The correct sequence of structures in the auditory pathway, beginning from the receptors (cochlea) and moving towards the auditory cortex, is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion: The auditory nerve fibers originate here.

 

3. Cochlear Nucleus: The auditory nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

6. Olivary complex: After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary complex.

 

4. Lateral lemniscus: From the superior olivary complex, the auditory signals travel via the lateral lemniscus.

 

5. Inferior colliculus: The lateral lemniscus projects to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

7. Medial geniculate body: The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

1. Auditory Cortex: Finally, the signals reach the auditory cortex (Area 41) in the temporal lobe for processing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

AUDITORY PATHWAY

 

E – Eighth nerve

 

C – Cochlear nucleus

 

O – Olivary complex (superior)

 

L – Lateral lemniscus

 

I – Inferior colliculus

 

M – Medial geniculate body

 

A – Auditory cortex

questions.text: What is the definitive approach for managing uncontrollable vertigo caused by Meniere's disease?(AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Labyrinthectomy

 

Definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniere’s disease is labyrinthectomy.

 

The step-up management of Meniere’s disease is

 

  1. Dietary changes – low salt and caffeine free diet
  2. First-line medical treatment to prevent recurrence of vertigo may include betahistine dihydrochloride 16 mg thrice daily and/or diuretics. Betahistine has a limited side effect profile while diuretics can cause electrolyte disturbances, potentially interacting with patient-specific drugs and conditions.
  3. Salvage treatment in case of medical treatment failure may include repetitive intratympanic injections of dexamethasone.
  4. In refractory cases after intratympanic injection of dexamethasone, intratympanic injection of gentamicin (as-needed) can be offered (recommendation grade A). This treatment is based on the vestibulotoxic effect of gentamicin and aims to destroy vestibular hair cell function (therefore also called partial chemo labyrinthectomy).
  5. Surgical destruction (Labyrinthectomy, Vestibular nerve section): Labyrinthectomy totally destroys cochlear and vestibular function and are thus used only when cochlear function is not serviceable and when conservative treatments fail. It has shown the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), and is considered as the single definitive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetazolamide: This medication is not typically used as a definitive treatment for Meniere's disease. It may be used in some cases for its diuretic effect to manage symptoms, but it does not address the root causes or provide long-term control of vertigo.

 

Option C. Vestibular neurectomy: This surgical procedure involves severing the vestibular nerve to alleviate vertigo while preserving hearing. It is considered for patients where hearing preservation is a priority, but it is not as definitive as labyrinthectomy for completely eliminating vertigo.

 

Option D. Intratympanic gentamicin: This treatment involves injecting gentamicin, a vestibulotoxic antibiotic, into the middle ear to chemically ablate vestibular function. It is used as a salvage treatment for vertigo control in Meniere's disease when other medical treatments fail. However, it is not considered as definitive as labyrinthectomy due to its potential for hearing loss and the need for repeated treatments in some cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with Meniere's disease who have debilitating vertigo and no serviceable hearing in the affected ear, labyrinthectomy offers a definitive solution with a very high success rate in eliminating vertigo. This surgical option is reserved for severe cases where other less invasive treatments have been exhausted.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of hearing loss and can understand only shouted or amplified speech. What would be the degree of impairment according to the WHO classification of ability to understand speech? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe hearing loss

Severe hearing loss means that individuals cannot hear most conversations. They typically only hear very loud sounds, such as a raised voice or sounds above 61 to 80 dB. They may not understand speech at normal levels and usually require powerful hearing aids or cochlear implants to assist their hearing. These individuals may rely more on lip reading or sign language.

Other Options:

Option A. Mild hearing loss: Individuals with mild hearing loss typically have difficulty understanding speech, especially in noisy situations. The hearing loss ranges between 26 and 40 decibels (dB). They can usually hear well in one-to-one conversations and might only struggle in noisier environments.

Option B. Moderate hearing loss: With moderate hearing loss, individuals have difficulty understanding regular speech, even at close distances. The hearing loss is between 41 and 60 dB. They often require some form of hearing assistance for daily activities and may benefit significantly from hearing aids.

Option D. Profound hearing loss: Profound hearing loss indicates that individuals cannot hear any speech and only very loud sounds exceeding 81 dB, such as that from heavy machinery or loud horns. Conversational speech is not audible at all. Persons with profound hearing loss rely on visual communication methods like sign language and may be candidates for cochlear implants.

Educational Objective: 

The case scenario described above points towards Severe hearing loss in the patient.

questions.text: Please identify the retractor depicted in the image below:(INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mollison's mastoid retractor

 

  • The instrument shown in the above image is Mollison's mastoid retractor.
  • It is used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Joll's retractor is used in thyroid surgery. It is self-retaining retractor.

 

 

Option B. Perkins retractor is used to open small incisions with minimal damage to surrounding tissues.

 

 

Option D. Langenbeck retractor is used to hold back, edges of incisions, tissue or organs

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mollison's Mastoid retractor is specifically tailored for ear surgeries, particularly mastoidectomy, where precise and sustained retraction of soft tissues is crucial. Understanding the specific applications and features of various retractors enhances surgical efficiency and safety.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

  •  Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.
  •  Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.
  • Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.
  •  Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Submental endotracheal intubation

questions.text: A construction worker was brought to the trauma center after a heavy concrete block fell on his face, causing severe maxillofacial and laryngeal injuries. He could not open his mouth, and examination revealed multiple fractures with obstructions in both the nasopharynx and oropharynx. To secure a patent airway, a specific procedure was performed. Which of the following options correctly describes the procedure? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cricothyroidotomy


Cricothyroidotomy is an emergency procedure performed when other methods of securing an airway are not feasible due to severe maxillofacial trauma, as seen in this patient. The procedure involves making an incision through the skin and cricothyroid membrane to establish an airway. This approach is life-saving and often used as a temporizing measure until a more definitive airway can be established. It is particularly indicated in situations where orotracheal and nasotracheal intubation are contraindicated due to obstructions or severe facial injuries.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Submental endotracheal intubation: This involves inserting an endotracheal tube through a submental incision, which is not suitable in the presence of significant maxillofacial trauma preventing mouth opening.
 

Option B. Emergency tracheostomy: Although it also provides a patent airway, tracheostomy is generally more time-consuming and requires more surgical expertise, making it less suitable for immediate emergency scenarios compared to cricothyroidotomy.
 

Option D. Subcutaneous tracheostomy: This term is not commonly used to describe an airway procedure, and thus does not correctly define the procedure performed in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Cricothyroidotomy is a quick and effective emergency procedure used to establish an airway in patients with severe facial trauma or other obstructions where traditional intubation methods are not possible

questions.text: A gentleman presents to the OPD with a saddle nose deformity. He gives a past history of cough, on/off fever, and hemoptysis. On examination, septal perforation is present with pale granuloma. His chest x-ray showed multiple cavitary lesions, and the biopsy showed granuloma, multinucleated giant cells, and caseous necrosis. What would be the probable cause? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

 

Generalized symptoms of fever, productive cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis along with chest x-ray showing multiple cavitation lesions are suggestive of tuberculosis. This diagnosis is supported by:

 

  • Chest X-ray: Presence of multiple cavitary lesions, which are characteristic of pulmonary TB.
  • Biopsy Findings: The presence of granulomas, multinucleated giant cells (Langhans type), and caseous necrosis is indicative of TB, which involves granulomatous inflammation with a distinctive type of necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wegener's Granulomatosis: This could also present with nasal deformity and granulomas but is usually associated with vasculitis and lacks the caseous necrosis typical of TB.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Can cause nasal collapse ("saddle nose") but typically does not present with the lung involvement seen in TB.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis: Also presents with granulomas but lacks the caseous necrosis seen in TB and typically shows non-cavitary lung lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis should be considered in patients presenting with respiratory symptoms, systemic signs, and nasal deformities when accompanied by histological evidence of caseating granulomas. This constellation of findings is distinct in suggesting TB over other granulomatous diseases.

 

Granulomatous Disease of the Nose:

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trismus

 

  • Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space.
  • Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vocal cord palsy: This could manifest due to involvement of the cranial nerves (CN IX, X, XI, XII) that are located in the post-styloid compartment. CN X (vagus nerve) palsy particularly can lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option C. Parotid swelling: Swelling in this region may occur as the post-styloid compartment is adjacent to the parotid gland and includes inflammatory processes that might extend into the parotid space.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: This syndrome may appear if the sympathetic chain, which runs through the post-styloid compartment, is affected by an infection or its related inflammatory processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:

 

Bulge behind posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

  • Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen.
  • Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome.
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • No trismus or minimal trismus
  • General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion.
  • Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.

 

Treatment

 

  • IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover
  • Incision and drainage of abscess

questions.text: CT scan of a patient with laryngeal carcinoma is shown below. Single ipsilateral < 3cm node is seen. What is the staging? (INICET NOVEMBER 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T4N1M0

The given CT image is consistent with a staging of T4N1M0. It depicts a large glottic-subglottic mass with massive cricoid and thyroid invasion and extra laryngeal spread indicating a T4 stage.

Above shown is CT scan of a 72-year-old patient with T4a laryngeal cancer (red arrows) showing a large extralaryngeal extension through the left side of the thyroid cartilage. Indication of primary total laryngectomy.

Other Options:

Option A. T1N0M0: Would indicate a tumor confined to one subsite with no lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, which does not correlate with the extensive involvement shown in the image.

Option C. T2N1M0: Suggests tumor involvement of adjacent subsites or impaired vocal cord mobility, which is less extensive than that shown.

Option D. T3N0M0: Indicates more advanced local disease than T2 but without the extensive extra-laryngeal spread or significant lymph node involvement shown in the image.

Educational Objective:

TNM STAGING FOR CA LARYNX:

T1 – Only 1 subsite (supraglottis/glottis/subglottis)

T2 – Involves adjacent subsites or sites, impaired vocal cord mobility.

T3 – Involving Pre-epiglottic space & post-cricoid area, fixed vocal cords.

T4a – Local invasion through thyroid cartilage or tissues beyond larynx

T4b – Invasion to distant places (prevertebral space, mediastinum, carotid, etc)

N0 – No cervical lymph nodes

N1 – Single ipsilateral < 3cm

N2 – Single ipsilateral 3-6cm / multiple ipsilateral, contralateral or bilateral < 6cm

N3 – Single or multiple nodes > 6cm

M0 – No metastasis

M1 – Metastasis present

Ref: Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 348

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency with epistaxis. There was no relief on pinching the nostrils. Nasal packing was done but the patient still continues to bleed. What would be the next appropriate step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ligation of sphenopalatine artery

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation should be considered in cases where epistaxis is not controlled by trotters method or nasal packing.

 

Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point.

 

Most common artery to be ligated for epistaxis is Sphenopalatine artery followed by internal maxillary artery, External carotid artery, Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ligation of external carotid artery: The external carotid artery is a major artery that supplies blood to numerous facial structures, including the scalp, face, jaw, and more. Ligation of this artery is generally considered a more drastic measure and is typically reserved for severe cases where other specific arterial sources of bleeding have been ruled out or are inaccessible. It is much less selective than targeting the sphenopalatine artery and can lead to significant complications due to reduced blood flow to essential tissues.

 

Option B. Ligation of internal carotid artery: This option is generally not considered for epistaxis management due to the critical nature of the internal carotid artery, which primarily supplies blood to the brain. Ligation of this artery would pose a high risk of serious neurological deficits or stroke. It is a major artery and not a contributor to nasal bleeding; thus, it is not targeted in the treatment of epistaxis.

 

Option D. Ligation of maxillary artery: The maxillary artery is a major artery within the face that branches off the external carotid artery and gives rise to the sphenopalatine artery. While ligation of the maxillary artery is an option for severe epistaxis, it is less specific than targeting the sphenopalatine artery. The maxillary artery supplies areas broader than just the nasal cavity, including the maxilla, mandible, teeth, and parts of the face. Therefore, ligation of this artery is considered more invasive and has a higher risk of complications compared to the sphenopalatine artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphenopalatine artery ligation is a highly effective surgical procedure for controlling severe or refractory epistaxis after more conservative measures have failed. This approach targets a primary blood supply to the nasal cavity, significantly reducing the risk of further bleeding.

choices.text: Behavioral audiometry, Speech audiometry, Tuning fork test
Otoacoustic emissions (OAE), Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA), Tympanometry
Pure-tone audiometry, Speech recognition threshold, Acoustic reflex testing
Whisper test, Rinne test, Weber test

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the ENT clinic with complaints of progressive hearing loss in both ears over the past six months. She describes difficulty hearing in crowded environments and sometimes struggles to understand conversations, especially on the phone. She denies any tinnitus, ear pain, or history of trauma. The physical examination of the ears is unremarkable. To further evaluate her hearing function, the physician decides to perform objective tests that do not require active participation or subjective responses from the patient. Which of the following objective tests are commonly used to assess hearing function?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Otoacoustic emissions (OAE), Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA), Tympanometry

 


The objective tests commonly used to assess hearing function include Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE), Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA), and Tympanometry. OAE tests measure sound waves generated by the outer hair cells of the cochlea and do not require patient responses. BERA assesses the electrical activity in the auditory pathway from the inner ear to the brainstem, helping to detect auditory nerve and brainstem function without the patient’s active participation. Tympanometry measures the mobility of the tympanic membrane and middle ear pressure, providing valuable information on middle ear status but also functioning as an objective test that does not need the patient's subjective feedback.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Behavioral audiometry, Speech audiometry, Tuning fork test: These are subjective tests that rely on the patient’s responses to sounds and are used to assess hearing thresholds and speech recognition but require active participation.

 

Option C. Pure-tone audiometry, Speech recognition threshold, Acoustic reflex testing: Pure-tone audiometry and speech recognition threshold are subjective measures of hearing that require patient feedback, while acoustic reflex testing is objective but specifically assesses the reflex pathway of the middle ear, not overall hearing function.

 

Option D. Whisper test, Rinne test, Weber test: These bedside tests are quick screening tools used to assess hearing and distinguish between conductive and sensorineural hearing loss, but they are subjective and require patient participation.

 

Educational Objective:


Objective hearing tests such as Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE), Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA), and Tympanometry provide valuable information about hearing function without relying on the patient’s subjective responses. These tests are particularly useful in populations who cannot actively participate, such as infants or individuals with cognitive impairments.

questions.text: Which of these options is not a causal factor for head and neck malignancies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin A deficiency

 

Vitamin A deficiency is not recognized as a direct risk factor for head and neck malignancies. While vitamin A plays crucial roles in maintaining epithelial tissues and immune function, its deficiency primarily leads to issues like night blindness and immune deficiencies, rather than directly causing cancers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) infection: EBV is associated with various types of cancers, including nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It is a well-established risk factor for this specific type of head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. HPV (Human Papillomavirus) infection: HPV, particularly type 16, is a significant risk factor for oropharyngeal cancers. The virus can lead to cellular transformations that result in malignancy.

 

Option Betel nut: Consumption of betel nut, often part of a "paan" or betel quid, is a known risk factor for oral cancers, particularly in the gingivobuccal sulcus, common in regions where it is a cultural practice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The common risk factors known to cause head and neck malignancies includes:

 

  1. Alcohol use
  2. Tobacco use (smoking or chewing)
  3. Viruses
    1. HPV 16 - oropharyngeal cancer
    2. EBV – Nasopharyngeal cancer
  4. Paan (betel quid) – Oral cancers especially in gingivobuccal sulcus
  5. Preserved or salted food consumption - nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  6. Occupational exposure:
    1. Exposure to wood or nickel dust or formaldehyde - a risk factor for cancers of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity
    2. Radiation exposure is a risk factor for salivary gland tumors, thyroid gland carcinoma

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Super supraglottic swallow

 

Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation but in dysphagia to prevent aspiration of food.

 

The Super-Supraglottic Swallow technique is employed for patients experiencing diminished airway closure. To perform this technique, patients are directed to take a deep breath and tightly hold it while bearing down. They should maintain this breath hold and bear down as they swallow. Immediately after the swallow (before inhaling), they are instructed to cough, followed by a forceful swallow once more (before inhaling). This sequence is aimed at enhancing airway protection during swallowing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A tracheoesophageal prosthesis (TEP) is a one-way valve inserted through a tracheoesophageal puncture. Occlusion of the stoma shunts the exhaled air through the TEP into the esophagus producing vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter resulting in phonation.

Option B. Esophageal speech is phonation produced by vibration of the upper esophageal sphincter.

 

Option C. Polite yawning also called nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is indicated for olfaction rehabilitation post laryngectomy. This maneuver induces a negative pressure in the oral cavity and oropharynx, which generates a nasal airflow, enabling odorous substances to reach the olfactory epithelium again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Super supraglottic swallow technique is crucial for enhancing airway protection in dysphagia management but is not utilized in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation, where the focus is primarily on restoring voice and smell functions through other specialized techniques.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition 352, 353; Scott Brown 7th edition, Volume 2, Page No. 2090

questions.text: Following a surgical procedure on the lateral aspect of the skull base, the patient experiences postoperative aspiration. However, there is no alteration in the patient's voice. What could be the explanation for this?(AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Superior laryngeal nerve injury

 

  • The patient has an injury to the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN).
  • SLN motor supply – cricothyroid muscle → when affected causes change in voice only in high pitch
  • SLN sensory supply – Above level of vocal cords → when affected can cause aspiration.
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve doesn't provide either sensory or motor supply to the larynx so its lesion will not cause aspiration.
  • RLN supplies all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except cricothyroid > when affected will cause change in voice.
  • A high vagal injury will affect both SLN and RLN, hence can also be ruled out.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glossopharyngeal nerve injury: This nerve does not primarily provide sensory or motor innervation to the larynx; its involvement would not typically result in aspiration.

 

Option C. Recurrent laryngeal nerve injury: Injury to this nerve would more likely affect the voice since it innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid. It would lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option D. High vagal injury: An injury here would affect both the SLN and the recurrent laryngeal nerve, likely causing symptoms in both voice and swallowing mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the superior laryngeal nerve, particularly its internal branch, is a plausible explanation for the patient's aspiration post-surgery, especially when there is no accompanying change in voice quality. This suggests that the sensory function above the vocal cords is compromised, increasing the risk of aspiration without necessarily affecting voice modulation handled by the external laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: The radiograph presented below has been taken to enhance the evaluation of the frontal sinus. What is the widely used term for this particular perspective?(INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caldwell view

 

  • The above X ray shows the Caldwell view in which the frontal sinus is best seen.
  • Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position) is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15–20° caudally.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Frontal sinuses (Best Visualization).
    2. Ethmoid sinuses.
    3. Maxillary sinuses.
    4. Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone.
    5. Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea.
    6. Superior orbital fissure.
    7. Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water's view: Primarily used for examining the maxillary sinuses and can also show the frontal sinuses but with less clarity than the Caldwell view.

 

Option C. Pierre's view: This is not a standard term in radiographic terminology.

 

Option D. Towne's view: Used to visualize the occipital bone and foramen magnum, not typically used for sinus examination.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: From which of the following structures does the saccule develop? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pars inferior

 

The saccule develops from pars inferior.

 

Development of internal ear:

 

  • Development of the inner ear starts in the 3rd week of fetal life and is complete by the 16th week. Ectoderm in the region of hindbrain thickens to form an auditory placode, which is invaginated to form auditory vesicles or the otocyst. The latter then differentiates into the endolymphatic duct and sac; the utricle, the semicircular ducts; and saccule and the cochlea. Development of the phylogenetically older part of labyrinth—pars superior (semicircular canals and utricle) takes place earlier than pars inferior (saccule and cochlea).

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Saculus anterior - Not a term typically associated with the development of the ear's structures.

 

Option B. Saculus posterior - Similarly, this is not a recognized term in the developmental anatomy of the ear.

 

Option C. Pars superior - Incorrect, as this part contributes to the development of the semicircular canals and utricle, not the saccule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The developmental origins of the inner ear structures, such as the saccule from the pars inferior, is crucial for comprehending various auditory and vestibular functions, as well as pathologies associated with these areas.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 13

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with recurrent URTI, poor growth, high-arched palate, and impaired hearing. Tympanogram is given as follows. What would be the most appropriate management?(INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion 

 

The presentation of a child with a type B tympanometry curve indicates the likelihood of serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy as the underlying cause.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grommet insertion: While this can relieve middle ear effusion, it does not address the underlying adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option C. Myringotomy with grommet insertion: Similar to grommet insertion alone, this option does not address the root cause of adenoid hypertrophy.

 

Option D. Myringotomy: This procedure involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure or drain fluid but does not address the cause or provide a lasting solution like adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion is the most appropriate management for a child presenting with serous otitis media due to adenoid hypertrophy, addressing both the immediate symptoms and underlying cause.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex virus

 

The given image shows the life cycle of the herpes simplex virus (HSV).

 

The herpes virus is a linear double-stranded DNA virus with an icosahedral capsid. The envelope has glycoprotein spikes.

 

Steps of HSV replication:

 

  • The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane
  • Viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore.
  • Transcription of immediate-early genes - alpha-Proteins
  • Transcription of late genes produces y-proteins which consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.
  • Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids.
  • Viral particles which are enveloped, collect in the endoplasmic reticulum
  • They are transported to cell surface by a vesicular movement

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) virus is spherical, enveloped virus with an icosahedral shell and a cone-shaped core which encloses the ribonucleoproteins. It consists of two identical single-stranded, RNA copies, with the reverse transcriptase enzyme, which is a characteristic feature of retroviruses.

 

HIV virus life cycle.

 

 

Option C. The hepatitis B virus is a DNA virus. It has an outer envelope and an inner nucleocapsid. It contains two linear strands of DNA in a circular configuration. One of the strands (the plus strand is incomplete resulting in partially double stranded and partially single-stranded DNA.

 

 

Option D. Corona viruses: The genome of coronaviruses is made up of positive sense, unsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronaviruses are enclosed RNA viruses. They feature surface projections in the form of petals. In the cytoplasm, coronavirus nucleocapsids grow and mature by budding into cytoplasmic vesicles. The structure and life cycle of coronaviruses are depicted in the figures below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV), is characterized by steps involving the fusion of the virus with the plasma membrane, nuclear entry, transcription, replication, capsid assembly, glycosylation, and virus release.

questions.text: A patient presents with a mobile, warm to touch nodule in the neck. On the anaerobic culture of the biopsy material from this swelling, it showed colonies as shown in the image which had gram-positive branching rods on staining. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Penicillin

 

The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth suggestive of actinomycete infection of cervicofacial region also called as Lumpy jaw.

 

Culture characteristics - Grows slowly under anaerobic conditions, on blood or serum glucose agar at 37°C. After about a week, it appears as small, creamy-white, adherent colonies on blood agar. The colonies resemble breadcrumbs or the surface of ‘molar’ teeth.

 

Gram-positive filamentous branching rods. Non-motile, non-sporing and non-acid-fast. Clumps of the organisms can be seen as yellowish ‘sulphur granules’ in pus discharging from sinus tracts, or the granules can be squeezed out of the lesions.

 

Sensitive to penicillin, but prolonged courses up to 6 weeks are necessary for chronic infections. Oral penicillin such as amoxicillin are now popular. Clindamycin and erythromycin are effective in patients with penicillin allergy. Recalcitrant lesions respond well to tetracycline because of its good bone penetration. Surgical intervention may be necessary in chronic jaw lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Doxycycline: Effective for certain infections but not the first-line treatment for actinomycete infections.

 

Option B. Cotrimoxazole: Not typically used for actinomycete infections.

 

Option D. Surgical drainage: May be required as an adjunct to antibiotic therapy in chronic cases, but it is not the primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Penicillin is the drug of choice for treating actinomycete infections, particularly in cervicofacial cases presenting with nodules and characteristic colonies. Prolonged antibiotic therapy is necessary, and surgical intervention may be required for chronic lesions.

questions.text: According to the WHO definition of hearing loss, which of the following values is classified as profound hearing loss? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. >81 dB

 

Explanation:

 

The World Health Organization (WHO) classifies hearing loss based on the hearing threshold in the better ear, measured across key frequencies (500, 1000, 2000 Hz). A hearing threshold of >81 dB in the better ear is categorized as profound hearing loss, which includes cases of deafness. This classification helps in understanding the severity of hearing impairment and guides appropriate interventions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 61-71 dB: This range falls under severe hearing impairment, not profound hearing loss, according to the WHO classification.
 

Option C. >91 dB: Although this value indicates profound hearing loss, the WHO threshold begins at >81 dB, not >91 dB.
 

Option D. >101 dB: This value represents profound hearing loss, but the WHO definition starts at a lower threshold of >81 dB.

 

Educational Objective:


According to WHO, profound hearing loss is defined as a hearing threshold of >81 dB in the better ear

choices.text: B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers

 

Explanation  

 

The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

 

 

Pressure on a nerve due to sleeping with arms under the head leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. B fibers, which are generally involved in autonomic functions, are not the primary concern in this scenario involving motor and sensory disturbances.

 

Option C. C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers: Incorrect. It's the opposite; A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers, making them more likely to be compromised under mechanical compression.

 

Option D. Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves: Incorrect. The loss of function is not due to sleep per se but due to mechanical pressure affecting nerve conduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In situations where pressure is applied to nerves, such as sleeping with an arm in a compromising position, the larger, myelinated A fibers (including motor fibers) are more susceptible to disruption compared to the smaller, unmyelinated C fibers. This leads to a loss of motor function and normal touch sensation, while pain sensation remains relatively intact due to the resilience of C fibers to mechanical pressure.

 

Relative susceptibility of nerve fibres –

questions.text: A male patient with a psychotic disorder is receiving antipsychotic, antidepressant, and antihypertensive medication. He developed tachycardia and chest tightness all of a sudden. He was diagnosed with metabolic acidosis. The ECG revealed a widened QRS complex and a prolonged QT interval. Which of the following drugs is the cause of this? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amitriptyline

 

Amitriptyline is a tricyclic antidepressant (TCA). TCAs are known for their potential to cause significant cardiac toxicity, particularly in overdose situations. The mechanism includes:

 

  • Cardiac Sodium Channel Blockade: This leads to a widened QRS complex on the ECG.
  • Prolongation of QT Interval: TCAs can also block potassium channels, leading to a prolonged QT interval and potentially resulting in Torsades de pointes, a life-threatening arrhythmia.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: TCAs can cause metabolic acidosis due to their effects on the central nervous system and cardiovascular system, which can result in decreased perfusion and tissue hypoxia.

 

Management: In cases of TCA overdose, the treatment of choice is intravenous sodium bicarbonate, which helps to narrow the QRS complex and stabilize the cardiac membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amlodipine: Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker used for hypertension and angina. It does not typically cause a widened QRS complex or a prolonged QT interval and is not associated with metabolic acidosis in overdose situations.

 

Option C. Chlorthalidone: Chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic used for hypertension. It is not associated with the cardiac effects described (widened QRS, prolonged QT) or metabolic acidosis.

 

Option D. Enalapril: Enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor used for hypertension and heart failure. It does not typically cause a widened QRS complex or prolonged QT interval and is not associated with metabolic acidosis in overdose situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amitriptyline is a TCA which can lead to widened QRS complex in the ECG along with prolonged QT interval-leading to Torsades de pointes. The antidote used in Amitriptyline toxicity is Sodium Bicarbonate.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to the clinic. She already has twins by normal delivery. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G2P1

 

In obstetric history, gravida (G) refers to the number of pregnancies a woman has had, including the current pregnancy, regardless of the outcome or duration. Parity (P) refers to the number of pregnancies that have reached the period of viability (28 weeks in India). Each pregnancy is counted once, regardless of the number of fetuses (e.g., twins count as one pregnancy).

 

  • Gravida (G): Number of pregnancies, including the current one.
  • Parity (P): Number of pregnancies that have reached viability (28 weeks or more), not including the current pregnancy.

 

In this case:

 

  • The woman has had one previous pregnancy that resulted in the birth of twins.
  • She is currently pregnant with her second pregnancy.

 

Therefore, her obstetric score is:

 

  • G2 (Gravida 2): This is her second pregnancy.
  • P1 (Para 1): She has had one previous pregnancy that reached viability and resulted in the birth of twins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G3P2: This would imply she has had three pregnancies and two that reached viability, which is incorrect.

 

Option B. G3P1: This would imply she is in her third pregnancy, which is incorrect.

 

Option D. G2P2: This would imply she has had two previous pregnancies that reached viability, which is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obstetric scoring, twin pregnancies count as a single gravida, and the obstetric score for a woman with twins by normal delivery and currently pregnant should be G2P1.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive dyspnoea at rest and on exertion (e.g., climbing stairs). The patient also has a history of heart failure. Laboratory tests show a fasting plasma glucose of 136 mg/dL, haemoglobin (Hb) of 13 g%, and HbA1c of 7.8%, indicating poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. The physician needs to select an appropriate antidiabetic medication considering the patient's symptoms and medical condition. Which is the preferred antidiabetic drug in this patient?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

  • Dapagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that promotes glucose excretion through the urine. It has been shown to provide significant benefits in patients with type 2 diabetes and heart failure, including reducing the risk of hospitalization for heart failure and cardiovascular death. Given the patient's history of heart failure, dapagliflozin is a preferred choice due to its cardiovascular benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion. It is associated with a risk of hypoglycemia and weight gain, which might not be ideal for this patient considering the need to manage cardiovascular risk factors and avoid potential hypoglycemic episodes.

 

Option C. Metformin: Metformin is a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes due to its efficacy and safety profile. However, in this case, given the patient's history of heart failure, dapagliflozin may provide additional cardiovascular benefits that make it a more suitable choice.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that helps improve blood glucose control with a low risk of hypoglycemia and is weight neutral. While it is effective, it does not have the same cardiovascular benefits as dapagliflozin in patients with heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin is the preferred antidiabetic drug for this patient due to its proven benefits in reducing heart failure-related outcomes, making it particularly suitable for a patient with a history of heart failure and poorly controlled diabetes.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man, post-MI, had the following lab values. Which of the following must be his treatment plan? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

 

LDL - 125mg/dl

 

HDL - 33mg/dl

 

TGL - 270mg/dl
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atorvastatin 80 mg

 

Post-MI patients require aggressive management to reduce the risk of future cardiovascular events. The lab values indicate elevated LDL and triglycerides, along with low HDL. The treatment plan includes the use of high-intensity statin therapy, which is recommended to significantly lower LDL cholesterol as part of secondary prevention strategies in atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD). Atorvastatin 80 mg falls under the category of high-intensity statins and is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol significantly, which helps in reducing the risk of recurrent cardiovascular events.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rosuvastatin + fenofibrate: This combination might be considered if there were specific concerns about triglyceride levels that could not be managed by statin therapy alone. However, the primary goal post-MI is to manage LDL levels aggressively with high-intensity statins.

 

Option C. Fenofibrate: Fenofibrate primarily targets triglycerides and would not be the first choice when the primary objective is to lower LDL cholesterol post-MI.

 

Option D. Rosuvastatin 10 mg: While rosuvastatin is effective in lowering LDL cholesterol, a lower dose may not be sufficient for high-risk patients post-MI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The high-intensity statin therapy, such as atorvastatin 80 mg, is essential in the management of patients after an MI to reduce the risk of subsequent cardiovascular events, regardless of initial cholesterol levels. This approach aligns with guidelines that emphasize aggressive LDL reduction in patients with established cardiovascular disease.

choices.text: Primary hyperparathyroidism
Vitamin D toxicity
Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

questions.text: Most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients is (INICET Nov 2023
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignancy

 

Explanation:  

 

In hospitalized patients, the most common cause of hypercalcemia is malignancy. Malignancy-associated hypercalcemia often results from the secretion of parathyroid hormone-related peptide (PTHrP) by cancer cells, which mimics the effects of parathyroid hormone, leading to increased calcium levels. This is frequently seen in cancers such as breast cancer, lung cancer, and multiple myeloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary hyperparathyroidism: This is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in outpatients but not in hospitalized patients. It is characterized by elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) due to parathyroid gland hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma.

 

Option C. Vitamin D toxicity: Hypercalcemia can occur due to excessive intake of vitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium. However, it is not the most common cause in hospitalized patients.

 

Option D. Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia: This is a rare genetic condition characterized by benign hypercalcemia with low urinary calcium excretion. It mimics primary hyperparathyroidism but is less common and typically not seen as the most frequent cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignancy is the most common cause of hypercalcemia in hospitalized patients, often due to the secretion of PTHrP by cancer cells.

choices.text: Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid

questions.text: Which of the following is the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid


Fibrinolytic therapy involves the use of drugs (like alteplase, streptokinase, etc.) to break down blood clots. Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid (EACA) and tranexamic acid are antifibrinolytic agents that can be used to counteract bleeding due to excessive fibrinolysis, which can occur during or after fibrinolytic therapy. These work by inhibiting plasminogen activators and, to a lesser degree, plasmin activity, thereby reducing the breakdown of fibrin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protamine Sulphate: This is used as an antidote for heparin overdose, not for fibrinolytic therapy. Protamine sulphate binds to and inactivates heparin.

 

Option B. Dalteparin: Dalteparin is a low molecular weight heparin and is an anticoagulant itself. It is not used as an antidote for fibrinolytic therapy.

 

Option D. Alteplase: Alteplase is a fibrinolytic agent, not an antidote. It is used to dissolve blood clots in conditions like acute ischemic stroke, pulmonary embolism, and myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epsilon Amino Caproic Acid is the antidote for fibrinolytic therapy, used to counteract excessive bleeding due to fibrinolysis. It works by inhibiting plasminogen activators and stabilizing clots.

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.

  • Mechanism of Action: Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.
  • Administration: Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).

 

Uses of Tamoxifen:

  • Primary Prophylaxis: Used for the primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Risk Reduction: Reduces the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast.
  • Recurrence Prevention: Lowers the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in both ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is the drug used for treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen on breast tissue, thereby preventing the growth and spread of hormone-dependent cancer cells.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman accuses her office colleague of spiking her drink and raping her. Which test can be used to detect vaginal cells on a person who is accused of rape? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lugol's

 

Lugol's iodine test

 

Aim – It detects the vaginal cells present on the penis of a rape accused.

 

Method - A filter paper is used to swab the penis of the accused. This paper is then treated with Lugol's iodine solution. Vaginal epithelial cells, which contain glycogen, will react with the iodine to produce a brown color, indicating the presence of vaginal cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Florence: Florence test is used for the detection of semen. It is not relevant for detecting vaginal cells.

 

Option B. Barberio: Barberio test is used to detect spermine in semen. It is not useful for identifying vaginal cells.

 

Option D. Precipitin: Precipitin test is used for species identification to determine if the biological material is of human origin. It does not detect vaginal cells specifically.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lugol's iodine test is used to detect vaginal cells on the penis of a rape accused by identifying glycogen-containing epithelial cells, which turn brown when exposed to Lugol's iodine solution.

questions.text: Which of the following is involved in recognition and clearance of necrotic cells? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inflammasome

 

Inflammasomes are involved in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Inflammasomes are large cytosolic multiprotein complexes that assemble in response to detection of infection- or stress-associated stimuli and lead to the activation of caspase-1-mediated inflammatory responses, including cleavage and unconventional secretion of the leaderless proinflammatory cytokines IL-1β and IL-18, and initiation of an inflammatory form of cell death referred to as pyroptosis.

 

Inflammasomes are involved in pyroptosis, a process of programmed cell death distinct from apoptosis and necrosis. This process is dependent on caspases 1, 4, and 5 and is responsible for killing of infected cells. It occurs in the following sequence:

 

  • Activation of inflammasome complex by infected cells
  • This causes activation of caspase-1
  • This results in generation of IL-1, which is responsible for fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Toll-like receptors (TLRs): Toll-like receptors are pattern recognition receptors that detect pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) and play a significant role in initiating the innate immune response. However, they are not directly involved in the recognition or clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Option C. P selectin: P selectin is a cell adhesion molecule found on the surface of activated endothelial cells and platelets. It mediates the initial interactions between leukocytes and endothelial cells during inflammation, but it is not involved in the recognition or clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Option D. Manoreceptor: This appears to be a typographical error, possibly meant to refer to the mannose receptor. The mannose receptor is involved in recognizing microbial sugars and is part of the immune system's response to pathogens. However, it is not involved in the clearance of necrotic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inflammasomes are crucial in the recognition and clearance of necrotic cells by activating caspase-1 and inducing the secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines, as well as triggering pyroptosis, an inflammatory form of cell death.

choices.text: Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidas

questions.text: All of the following side effects are more commonly seen with carbamazepine than oxcarbazepine, except: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hyponatremia

 

  • Hyponatremia is more commonly observed in individuals taking oxcarbazepine compared to those taking carbamazepine.
  • Both of these antiepileptic drugs can contribute to hyponatremia by enhancing the effects of ADH (antidiuretic hormone), leading to increased retention of water, which in turn reduces the osmolarity and causes hyponatremia. However, the incidence of hyponatremia appears to be higher with oxcarbazepine when compared to carbamazepine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotension: Hypotension is more commonly seen with carbamazepine. It can affect cardiovascular function and lead to decreased blood pressure.

 

Option C. Rash: Rash is a common side effect of both drugs, but it is more frequently seen with carbamazepine. Skin reactions can range from mild to severe, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

 

Option D. Elevated levels of gamma glutamyl transpeptidases (GGT): Elevated GGT levels are more commonly associated with carbamazepine use. GGT is an enzyme found in the liver, and its elevated levels can indicate liver enzyme induction or liver injury, which is more common with carbamazepine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyponatremia is more commonly associated with oxcarbazepine than carbamazepine. While both drugs can cause similar side effects due to their similar mechanisms of action, certain adverse effects, such as hypotension, rash, and elevated GGT levels, are more frequently seen with carbamazepine.

choices.text: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a noticeable bulge in his lower abdomen that becomes more pronounced when he's in a standing position. Upon examination, hernia is identified located medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

 

  • The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a direct hernia.
  • Direct inguinal hernias protrude through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and are located medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • The appropriate surgical method for the management of a direct hernia is the Lichtenstein mesh repair.
  • The Lichtenstein mesh repair is a tension-free technique that uses a synthetic mesh to reinforce the weakened area of the abdominal wall.
  •  It is the preferred method for direct hernias due to its lower recurrence rates and faster recovery times.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct hernia and Bassini repair: While the Bassini repair is a traditional method of hernia repair, it involves suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic arches or conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament without using a mesh. This technique is mainly used in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis but has a high recurrence rate compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option C. Indirect hernia and Bassini repair: Incorrect. Indirect hernias are located lateral to the inferior epigastric artery and are managed differently. The Bassini repair, as mentioned, is less commonly used today due to its higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repairs.

 

Option D. Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair: Incorrect. While the Lichtenstein mesh repair can also be used for indirect hernias, the scenario describes a direct hernia based on its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia is characterized by its location medial to the inferior epigastric artery, and the Lichtenstein mesh repair is the recommended surgical approach due to its efficacy and lower recurrence rates.

choices.text: USG with doppler study of renal veins
CT of the abdomen

questions.text: What imaging test is useful in the evaluation of collecting system and to look for tumor thrombi in renal veins and inferior vena cava in a suspected case of Wilms tumor in a 3-year-old child? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) USG with doppler study of renal veins


USG with doppler study of renal veins is particularly useful in evaluating the renal veins and the inferior vena cava for the presence of tumor thrombi in cases of Wilms tumor. This non-invasive technique allows for real-time imaging and assessment of blood flow, which is crucial in the management and surgical planning for Wilms tumor, particularly in determining the extent of vascular involvement by the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plain radiography: This is not detailed enough for assessing tumor thrombi or detailed renal and vascular structures.

 

Option C. CT of the abdomen: While useful for overall disease staging and metastasis evaluation, it is not the first-line for assessing vascular involvement specifically.

 

Option D. MRI: Although MRI provides excellent soft tissue contrast and is useful in certain complex cases, it is not typically used initially due to the need for sedation in young children.

 

Educational Objective:


Understand the importance of USG with doppler study in the evaluation of the collecting system and detection of tumor thrombi in the renal veins and inferior vena cava in pediatric cases of Wilms tumor.

choices.text: Greater palatine artery
Superior labial artery

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of right-sided epistaxis that has persisted for the past hour. She reports that the bleeding began spontaneously and has been difficult to control despite applying pressure. She has had similar but less severe episodes in the past that usually stopped within a few minutes. There is no history of recent trauma or anticoagulant use. On examination, her blood pressure is 178/95 mmHg, and there is active bleeding from the anterior nasal septum. Nasal endoscopy confirms bleeding from Kiesselbach’s plexus. The physician discusses potential contributors to the vascular supply of this area and identifies arteries involved in the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which of the following arteries is NOT a branch of the external carotid artery contributing to Kiesselbach's plexus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anterior ethmoidal artery


The anterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery, which stems from the internal carotid artery. This origin makes it distinct from the other arteries that supply Kiesselbach’s plexus, as it is the only one not derived from the external carotid artery. Despite its involvement in the vascular network of the nasal septum, its internal carotid origin sets it apart in this richly vascularized area.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Sphenopalatine artery: This artery is a branch of the maxillary artery, part of the external carotid system, and is one of the primary suppliers of the nasal septum within Kiesselbach’s plexus.

 

Option B. Greater palatine artery: Arising from the maxillary artery, this artery is part of the external carotid system and contributes to the blood supply of Kiesselbach’s plexus through its septal branches.

 

Option C. Superior labial artery: A branch of the facial artery, originating from the external carotid system, it supplies the nasal septum through its septal branches, playing a key role in the vascular network of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

 

Educational Objective:

 


Kiesselbach’s plexus is a key site for epistaxis due to the rich anastomosis of arteries from both the external and internal carotid systems. The anterior ethmoidal artery, derived from the internal carotid via the ophthalmic artery, is the only artery within this plexus that is not part of the external carotid artery, emphasizing the complex nature of nasal blood supply.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked a in the image given below? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar artery

 

 

The structure marked in the image is the ulnar artery, seen contributing to the superficial palmar arch.

 

It is a major blood vessel of the forearm that passes alongside the ulna bone. It is essential for supplying blood to the deep and superficial structures of the forearm and hand. In the wrist, the ulnar artery passes through Guyon's canal before contributing to both the superficial and deep palmar arches.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: Incorrect because the ulnar nerve, while it travels a similar path as the ulnar artery in the forearm, is not a blood vessel but a nerve. It primarily provides sensory and motor innervation to the hand, not blood supply.

 

Option C. Superficial radial artery: Incorrect as this artery travels along the radial side of the forearm and would not be located where the marked structure is. The superficial radial artery is much smaller and does not contribute significantly to the palmar arches.

 

Option D. Median nerve: Incorrect because, like the ulnar nerve, the median nerve is a neural structure responsible for sensory and motor functions in the forearm and hand, not a vascular structure. It travels down the middle of the forearm and does not supply blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar artery is an essential vascular structure for the blood supply to the forearm and hand, particularly contributing to the formation of the palmar arches, which are critical for hand perfusion. Its course alongside the ulna bone and through Guyon's canal makes it a significant artery in the vascular anatomy of the forearm and hand. It passes deep to the Guyon's canal in the wrist and contributes to the superficial and deep palmar arch.

questions.text: In a village, the residents find a new groundwater source. After intake of water from this source many villagers presented with nausea, vomiting, dark bloody stools, conjunctivitis, and a burning sensation in the throat and stomach. Which poisoning do you suspect in this case? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Arsenic

 

The given clinical scenario points towards arsenic poisoning

 

Causes of arsenic poisoning: Arsenic poisoning occurs most often in major areas of agriculture and industrialization. It occurs through contaminated groundwater, air, soil or food.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Potassium permanganate: Typically causes caustic injuries, including severe mucosal burns upon ingestion, but not the full range of symptoms described.

 

Option C. Thallium: Causes symptoms such as gastrointestinal distress, neurological symptoms, and hair loss, but does not match the full clinical picture described.

 

Option D. Lead: Lead poisoning causes anemia, abdominal pain, neurological symptoms, and kidney damage, but does not match the described symptoms of conjunctivitis and burning sensation in the throat and stomach.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Stage the bedsore in the following image: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4

 

The image depicts a Stage 4 pressure ulcer (bedsore), which is characterized by deep tissue loss that exposes underlying structures such as muscle, bone, or supporting tissues. Stage 4 is the most severe form of pressure ulcer, often showing significant tissue necrosis, deep crater formation, and the possibility of undermining or tunneling under the skin.

 

 

Educational Objective:
