Stage 4 pressure ulcers are characterized by full-thickness tissue loss with visible muscle, bone, or supporting structures, making them the most severe and challenging to manage.

choices.text: B and C
A and B
A, B, C

questions.text:
Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Dexamethasone

B. Remdesivir

C. Favipiravir
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only A

 

  • In severe COVID-19 infection, there is a systemic inflammatory response, which can lead to lung injury and multiple organ dysfunction. Corticosteroids, due to their anti-inflammatory effect, can help mitigate these negative effects and reduce the mortality in patients.
  • Only dexamethasone has been shown to reduce mortality in severe covid19 cases.
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IV/PO once daily for 10 days or until hospital discharge is given in severe cases. In the absence of dexamethasone, equivalent doses of other corticosteroids such as prednisone, methylprednisone, or hydrocortisone may be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remdesivir

 

  • Mechanism: Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used to reduce the duration of illness in COVID-19 patients, but it has not been conclusively shown to reduce mortality.

 

Option C. Favipiravir

 

  • Mechanism: Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used in some countries for the treatment of COVID-19, but there is no strong evidence to support a reduction in mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is the only drug among the listed options that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe COVID-19 cases, due to its potent anti-inflammatory effects. Remdesivir and favipiravir have not demonstrated a mortality benefit.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis

 

The histopathological picture of the caseating granuloma, eosinophilic necrotic debris known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells (horse shoe shape), and lymphocytes, as well as the clinical history, indicate tuberculosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES: Tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, fever, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leprosy: Skin lesions and nerve involvement with loss of sensation.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions, non-caseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Thickened capsule/ hyperplasia of capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation, and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis is characterized by caseating granulomas with eosinophilic necrotic debris, surrounded by epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes. This histopathological pattern, along with the clinical presentation of chronic cough and cervical lymphadenopathy, is indicative of tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the head and neck surgery clinic with complaints of swelling and discomfort in his cheek that has progressively worsened over the past few months. Imaging reveals a mass in the maxillary sinus extending towards the orbit. The surgeon explains that the prognosis and surgical approach will depend on the location of the tumor relative to a specific anatomical reference line used in the classification of maxillary carcinomas. The blue dashed line in the image is used to help determine the prognosis of maxillary sinus tumors. What anatomical reference or line is represented by the blue dashed line shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ohngren’s line

 


Ohngren’s line is an imaginary line passing through the medial canthus of the eye and the angle of the mandible. It is used for the classification of maxillary sinus carcinomas, dividing the maxillary antrum into a suprastructure and infrastructure. Tumors located above Ohngren’s line (suprastructure) generally have a poor prognosis due to their proximity to critical structures like the orbit, skull base, and cranial nerves. Tumors located below the line (infrastructure) have a better prognosis because they are less likely to invade these vital areas, making surgical resection more feasible.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Camper’s line: Camper’s line, or the plane of occlusion, is an anatomical reference that runs from the ala of the nose to the tragus of the ear. It is used primarily in prosthodontics to align dental prostheses, not for maxillary carcinoma classification.

 

Option C. McGregor’s line: McGregor’s line is an anatomical reference used to assess basilar invagination on lateral skull radiographs. It extends from the posterior edge of the hard palate to the lowest point of the occipital bone and is unrelated to maxillary sinus tumors.

 

Option D. Reid’s base line: Reid’s base line, also known as the anthropological or Frankfurt horizontal line, runs from the infraorbital margin to the external auditory meatus. It is used in radiology for standardizing head positions in imaging and is not involved in the classification of maxillary carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:


Ohngren’s line is an anatomical reference line that runs from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible, used to classify maxillary sinus carcinomas into suprastructure and infrastructure. This classification helps determine the tumor’s prognosis and guides surgical planning based on the tumor’s location relative to this line.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has experienced the loss of her newborn. She is currently producing breast milk, leading to discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. Which of the following drug can be used to prevent this complication? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cabergoline

 

In this scenario, the goal is to prevent lactation to avoid discomfort and the risk of developing a breast abscess due to milk stasis and incomplete emptying. The appropriate treatment involves using a drug that can suppress prolactin secretion, as prolactin is the hormone responsible for stimulating milk production.

 

Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion, effectively suppressing lactation. It is often used for this purpose and can be an effective choice in this situation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an antiprogestin used for medical termination of pregnancy. It does not have a direct role in suppressing lactation.

 

Option C. Chlorpromazine: Chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic medication that can increase prolactin levels, which would not be helpful in this context.

 

Option D. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide is a prokinetic agent and antiemetic that also increases prolactin levels, making it unsuitable for suppressing lactation.

 

Given these options, the correct choice for preventing lactation and thus avoiding the associated complications is: b. Cabergoline

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, the height and weight are lesser than expected. Laboratory investigations were positive for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following will you advise the child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gluten-free diet

 

The positive HLA-DQ2 and the presentation of diarrhea and weight loss in a child suggest the possibility of celiac disease. Therefore, the child should be advised to follow a gluten-free diet.

 

Celiac disease is a condition characterized by an abnormal immune response to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. This immune response leads to damage to the small intestine and malabsorption of nutrients, which can result in diarrhea, weight loss, and other symptoms.

 

HLA-DQ2 is a genetic marker that is present in over 90% of individuals with celiac disease. Therefore, a positive test for HLA-DQ2 can suggest the possibility of celiac disease, although a definitive diagnosis requires further testing, such as serologic testing and intestinal biopsy.

 

The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin, a gluten-derived peptide. In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by an intestinal enzyme called tissue transglutaminase (tTG), resulting in a more immunogenic form of the protein that is presented to helper T cells. This leads to mucosal inflammation, tissue damage, and other symptoms.

 

Children with celiac disease typically present with diarrhea, weight loss, and growth failure. Other symptoms may include malabsorption, bloating, irregular bowel habits, iron deficiency anemia, osteoporosis, ataxia, and abnormal liver enzymes. Screening for celiac disease is performed by testing for serum antibodies, including tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deaminated anti-gliadin antibodies. The diagnosis is confirmed in patients with positive antibodies by biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. Microscopic examination of the biopsy sample reveals intraepithelial CD8+ lymphocytes, villous atrophy, and crypt hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fat-free diet: This is not relevant to the management of celiac disease. Fat intake is not directly related to the immune response triggered by gluten.

 

Option B. Lactose-free diet: While some individuals with celiac disease may temporarily develop lactose intolerance due to mucosal damage, a lactose-free diet is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Low carbohydrate diet: This diet is not related to the management of celiac disease. The primary issue is the immune response to gluten, not carbohydrate intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with celiac disease should follow a gluten-free diet to manage symptoms and prevent further intestinal damage.

questions.text: An individual experienced a dog bite. Both the person and the dog are up-to-date with their vaccinations. The person's medical history includes a splenectomy performed five years ago. What is the optimal course of action for managing this situation? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Amoxiclav

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate (Augmentin) is generally considered the first-line prophylactic treatment for animal bites.
  • Appropriate tetanus and rabies prophylaxis as indicated should also be a part of caring for a patient who has sustained a dog bite, as well as local debridement and thorough cleaning of the wound

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation: Observation alone is not sufficient due to the risk of infection, especially in an asplenic individual.

 

Option C. Metronidazole: This antibiotic is not typically used as monotherapy for animal bites as it does not cover the range of bacteria commonly involved.

 

Option D. Ciprofloxacin: While it has some coverage, it is not the first-line treatment for dog bites and lacks the broad coverage provided by amoxicillin/clavulanate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amoxicillin/clavulanate is the optimal course of action for prophylactic treatment following a dog bite, especially in individuals with increased infection risk, such as those with a history of splenectomy.
  • Thorough wound care and appropriate prophylaxis for tetanus and rabies should also be part of the management plan.

questions.text: A drug solution containing 500 mg/5 ml of the drug is given to you. You are provided with a 2 ml syringe (having 10 divisions for each mI). How many divisions of the 2 m syringe need to be administered to deliver 180 mg of the drug to a patient? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 18

 

500 mg of the drug is present in 5ml of the solution.

 

Therefore, 180 mg will be present in (5/500) *180 = 1.8ml

 

In the syringe provided, 1ml = 10 divisions,

 

Therefore 1.8ml = 18 divisions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To deliver 180 mg of the drug using the provided 2 ml syringe with 10 divisions per ml, you need to fill the syringe to 18 divisions.

questions.text: Injury to which of the following nerves most commonly results in foot drop? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Common peroneal nerve

 

Common Peroneal Nerve (also known as Common Fibular Nerve) is the nerve primarily responsible for foot drop when injured.

 

  • Origin: The common peroneal nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve, which splits into the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve near the apex of the popliteal fossa.
  • Function: It innervates the muscles of the anterior and lateral compartments of the leg, such as the tibialis anterior, which dorsiflexes the ankle. An injury to this nerve can result in the inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to "foot drop."
  • Common injury sites: This nerve can be compromised at the fibular head where it is superficial, making it susceptible to injuries.      

 

 

Hence, injury to the common peroneal nerve will lead to:

 

  • Weakness of dorsiflexion of foot or foot drop
  • Loss of eversion
  • Loss of extension of toes
  • Sensory loss
    • Anterior and lateral side of the leg
    • Dorsum of the foot including the medial side of the great toe

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Femoral Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the lumbar plexus and is composed of fibers from the L2 to L4 nerve roots.
  • Function: Primarily innervates the anterior thigh muscles like the quadriceps, which are responsible for knee extension. It also provides sensation to the anterior thigh and medial leg.
  • If injured: A person may have difficulty in extending the knee and reduced sensation in the innervation area, but it will not cause foot drop.

 

Option C. Tibial Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Another branch of the sciatic nerve.
  • Function: It innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg, which are primarily responsible for plantarflexion of the ankle and flexion of the toes.
  • If injured: A person may have difficulty in plantarflexing the ankle or flexing the toes and may have a loss of sensation in the sole of the foot, but foot drop is not a symptom.

 

Option D. Sciatic Nerve:

 

  • Origin: The largest nerve in the body, originating from the sacral plexus with roots from L4 to S3.
  • Function: Innervates much of the posterior thigh, all of the leg except for a small medial area, and most of the foot.
  • If injured: Since the sciatic nerve gives rise to both the tibial and common peroneal nerves, injury can cause a range of motor and sensory deficits in the leg, depending on the injury's location. However, an injury specifically leading to foot drop would more directly implicate its common peroneal branch rather than the entire sciatic nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 1 month
3 months
No need to stop
Can be stopped and conceived soon after stopping

questions.text: A lady who had undergone mastectomy for breast cancer is being treated with tamoxifen. How long should it be stopped for before she can conceive?  (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 months

 

  • Tamoxifen is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM), which is used in Premenopausal women having ER +ve breast cancer, because of its anti-estrogenic action in the breast. It prevents the chance of recurrence of breast cancer after surgery.
  • The half-life of tamoxifen is approximately 5 to 7 days, but its active metabolites can persist in the body for several weeks. To minimize any risk to a potential pregnancy, it is recommended to stop tamoxifen at least 3 months before trying to conceive.
  • Tamoxifen has teratogenic effects, such as craniofacial abnormalities and reproductive tract abnormalities. It is also stopped during lactation as it is secreted in breast milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen should be stopped for at least 3 months before attempting to conceive due to its long half-life and potential teratogenic effects. This ensures that the drug and its active metabolites are sufficiently cleared from the body, reducing the risk of harm to the fetus.

choices.text: Work only when in close conjugation with promoter region
Work only when in upstream of promoter region
They are very specific to the gene
Recruit chromatin and modify regulatory mechanisms

questions.text: True statement about the action of enhancers of gene expression?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recruit chromatin and modify regulatory mechanisms

 

  • This statement is correct. The primary function of enhancers is to recruit transcription factors and other regulatory proteins, which in turn modify chromatin structure and regulatory mechanisms. Enhancers play a crucial role in creating an open chromatin environment, making the promoter region accessible to transcription machinery, and enhancing gene expression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Work only when in close conjugation with the promoter region: This statement is not entirely accurate. Enhancers do not have to be in close proximity to the promoter region to function. Enhancers can be located at varying distances from the promoter, even thousands of base pairs away. They exert their regulatory influence through long-range DNA looping interactions, so physical closeness is not a strict requirement.

 

Option B. Work only when in upstream of the promoter region: This statement is also incorrect. Enhancers can be located both upstream and downstream of the promoter region. They can even be within introns or elsewhere in the gene or intergenic regions. The position relative to the promoter varies and does not determine their functionality.

 

Option C. They are very specific to the gene: Enhancers are not always gene-specific. Some enhancers can influence multiple genes, especially in gene clusters. Their specificity is often determined by the combination of transcription factors they bind to and chromatin structure. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enhancers: Enhancers are regulatory DNA sequences that play a crucial role in controlling gene expression. They can be located at varying distances from the gene they regulate and can function independently of their orientation or location (upstream, downstream, or within an intron). Enhancers work by recruiting transcription factors and other regulatory proteins. These proteins, in turn, facilitate the binding of RNA polymerase to the promoter region, ultimately leading to the initiation of transcription.  Enhancers can also recruit chromatin-modifying enzymes, leading to changes in chromatin structure and accessibility. This chromatin modification is a key mechanism in the regulation of gene expression.

 

Characteristics of Enhancers:

 

  1. Distance: Enhancers can act over long distances. They are not necessarily proximal to the promoter; they can be located upstream, downstream, or within an intron of the gene.
  2. Orientation: Enhancers can function in either orientation relative to the gene.
  3. Specificity: Enhancers are not always specific to a single gene; they can regulate the expression of multiple genes, and one gene can be regulated by multiple enhancers.

choices.text: Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
Facial nerve (CN VII)
Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII)
Cervical nerves C2, C3

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the ENT clinic with severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and ear pain that started a few days ago. She reports that the ear pain is particularly bothersome, although she has no history of ear infections or recent trauma. On examination, her tonsils are markedly swollen with erythema and exudates, consistent with acute tonsillitis. Otoscopic examination of the ears is unremarkable, with normal tympanic membranes and no signs of middle ear infection. The physician explains that the ear pain is referred rather than primary, related to the inflamed tonsillar region. Which nerve is primarily responsible for referred ear pain (otalgia) associated with tonsillitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

 


The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) provides sensory innervation to the tonsils and tonsillar fossa, and it can transmit pain from these areas to the ear through its tympanic branch (Jacobson's nerve). This referred pain, known as otalgia, occurs because the glossopharyngeal nerve shares neural pathways that can transmit pain signals to the ear even though there is no primary ear pathology. This mechanism explains why patients with tonsillitis or other oropharyngeal inflammations often experience ear pain despite having normal ear examinations.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Facial nerve (CN VII): The facial nerve primarily provides motor innervation to the muscles of facial expression and has no significant role in transmitting sensory pain from the tonsillar region to the ear, making it irrelevant to referred otalgia from tonsillitis.

 

Option C. Hypoglossal nerve (CN XII): The hypoglossal nerve is mainly responsible for motor innervation to the muscles of the tongue and does not play a role in sensory pain referral to the ear, particularly from the tonsils.

 

Option D. Cervical nerves C2, C3: These nerves transmit referred pain from the cervical spine, contributing to neck and posterior ear pain but are not associated with referred otalgia from tonsillar inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:


Referred otalgia associated with tonsillitis is primarily mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), which transmits sensory information from the tonsils and tonsillar fossa to the ear through shared neural pathways. Understanding this mechanism helps in diagnosing referred ear pain when primary ear pathology is absent.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with 2-3 hypopigmented, slightly raised patches on his forearm with reduced sensation for 4 months. He is diagnosed with paucibacillary leprosy. What is the recommended treatment regimen? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) 2 drug therapy for 6 months

 

  • The treatment regimen for paucibacillary leprosy involves a 6-month course of drug therapy with 2 drugs (Dapsone, Rifampicin).
  • Diagnosis of leprosy under NLEP: It is currently based on clinical grounds (revised case definition) - 

 

Paucibacillary (PB) case: A case of leprosy with 1 to 5 skin lesions, without demonstrated presence of bacilli in a skin smear;

 

Multibacillary (MB) case: A case of leprosy with more than five skin lesions; or with nerve involvement (pure neuritis, or any number of skin lesions and neuritis); or with the demonstrated presence of bacilli in a slit-skin smear, irrespective of the number of skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

MDT blister pack Colour

 

PBL adult - Green color

 

MBL adult - Red color

 

PBL child - Blue color

 

MBL child - Yellow colour

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given staining technique? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia asteroids

 

The organism shown above is the Nocardia species. The above image shows acid-fast staining, where the organisms are shown appear as acid-fast (stained with fuschia) and branching rods or filaments. They are aerobes found particularly in the soil and are found to produce lung infections in the immunocompromised.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, B: Mycobacteria species are acid-fast but do not have branching filaments.

 

Option C: Actinomyces species is gram-positive but not acid-fast.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia species are partially acid-fast, branching, filamentous rods that are found in the soil and cause lung infections in immunocompromised individuals.

choices.text: Factor V Leiden mutation
Protein C deficiency
Antithrombin III deficiency
G20210A prothrombin gene mutation

questions.text: What is the most common genetic factor responsible for hypercoagulability? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Factor V Leiden mutation

 

Factor V Leiden mutation (Activated protein C resistance) is the most common inherited disorder that causes hypercoagulability.

 

The prothrombin G20210A mutation is the second most common inherited risk factor for thrombosis and leads to increased levels of prothrombin which demonstrates a higher risk for arterial and venous thrombotic events.

 

Protein C & S deficiency, Antithrombin III deficiency, Hyperhomocysteinemia, Elevated factor VIII (FVIII) are other causes of hypercoagulability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Protein C deficiency: Protein C deficiency is a rarer inherited condition that also increases the risk of venous thromboembolism due to impaired inactivation of Factors Va and VIIIa. However, it is less common than Factor V Leiden mutation.

 

Option C. Antithrombin III deficiency: This is another inherited disorder leading to hypercoagulability. Antithrombin III normally inhibits thrombin and other clotting factors, and its deficiency increases the risk of thrombosis. Again, it is less common than Factor V Leiden mutation.

 

Option D. G20210A prothrombin gene mutation: This mutation is the second most common inherited risk factor for thrombosis. It leads to increased levels of prothrombin, which is associated with a higher risk for both arterial and venous thrombotic events.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Factor V Leiden mutation is the most common inherited cause of hypercoagulability, primarily due to resistance to Activated Protein C.

choices.text: Oxidation of Fatty acids
None of the above

questions.text: In a 100-m dash, most of the energy consumed by skeletal muscles to replenish ATP is derived from? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phosphocreatine

 

Phosphocreatine (also called creatine phosphate) is another chemical compound that has a high-energy phosphate bond. The combined amounts of cell ATP and cell phosphocreatine are called the phosphagen energy system. These together can provide maximal muscle power for 8 to 10 seconds, almost enough for the 100-meter run.

 

Thus, the energy from the phosphagen system is used for maximal short bursts of muscle power.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aerobic glycolysis: This process occurs in the mitochondria and is used for longer-duration, lower-intensity exercise. It involves the oxidation of glucose to produce ATP, but it is too slow to meet the immediate energy demands of a 100-meter dash.

 

Option C. Oxidation of Fatty acids: This is a slower process involving the breakdown of fatty acids in the mitochondria to produce ATP. It primarily supports prolonged, steady-state activities rather than short bursts of high-intensity exercise.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect, as phosphocreatine is the primary source of rapid ATP replenishment during short, high-intensity activities like a 100-meter dash.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During a 100-meter dash, the primary source of energy for rapidly replenishing ATP in skeletal muscles is the phosphagen system, utilizing phosphocreatine for short bursts of maximal muscle power lasting approximately 8 to 10 seconds.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with weakness in his lower limbs and rash over the eyelids. The biopsy shows inflammation of the muscle. What is the finding shown in the image below? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules

 

  • The finding shown in the image is Gottron's papules.
  • The given scenario of a patient with weakness, rash on eyelids (Heliotrope Rash), muscle inflammation, and presence of Gottron's papules which are pathognomonic of dermatomyositis, especially in the paediatric population, known as Juvenile Dermatomyositis (JDM).
  • These are erythematous to violaceous papules or plaques found over bony prominences, particularly the knuckles, elbows, knees, and toes.

 

Other features associated with Dermatomyositis are:

 

The Gottron's sign

 

  • It is the distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign: seen in the above image

 

Other Options: 

 

Option C. Heliotrope rash

 

  • It is another characteristic finding of dermatomyositis, presenting as an erythematous to violaceous rash on the upper eyelids, often accompanied by periorbital edema.

 

 

Image showing Heliotrope rash:

 

  • While the patient has a rash over the eyelids, the image does not show this area.

 

Option B. Shawl sign or V-sign:

 

  • Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual telangiectasias: enlarged capillaries in the nail folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Option D. Scleroderma:

 

  • It is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and tightening, which can also involve internal organs. The lesions in scleroderma are not typically papular as shown in the image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In juvenile dermatomyositis, Gottron's papules are erythematous to violaceous raised lesions typically found over the extensor surfaces of joints and serve as a key clinical marker for the disease.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing? (INICET May 2021)

 

  1. BERA (Brainstem evoked response audiometry)
  2. OAE (Otoacoustic emission)
  3. PTA (Pure tone audiometry)
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4

 

Objective tests for hearing do not require the active cooperation or response from the patient and are thus particularly useful in non-cooperative subjects such as young children or those who might simulate hearing loss.

 

1. BERA - Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) is an objective test to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain

 

2. OAE is an objective test that records the low-intensity sounds produced by outer hair cells of a normal cochlea and can be elicited by a very sensitive microphone placed in the external ear canal and analyzed by a computer.

 

4. Tympanometry is an objective test for compliance or stiffness of the tympano-ossicular system. It evaluates the mobility of the eardrum (tympanic membrane) and the conduction bones of the middle ear, providing useful information about middle ear pressure and fluid presence.

 

Other Option:

 

3. PTA (pure tone audiometry): This is a subjective test as it relies on the patient's response to pure tone stimuli. It is not included as an objective test because it requires the patient's active participation to indicate when a sound is heard. Subjective tests such as PTA, tuning fork tests, and speech audiometry depend on patient interaction and are susceptible to voluntary or involuntary response errors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Objective hearing tests like BERA, OAE, and Tympanometry provide essential diagnostic information without the need for patient interaction, distinguishing them from subjective tests like Pure Tone Audiometry which rely on patient responses.

questions.text: What dye is used in staining the anterior capsule of the lens?(FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trypan blue

 

Trypan blue dye is commonly used to stain the anterior capsule of the lens during cataract surgery, specifically to facilitate the creation of a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis. This dye helps surgeons to visualize the capsule better, making the procedure safer and more precise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluorescein green: This dye is used to stain corneal epithelial defects and is not used for staining the anterior lens capsule.

 

Option C. Brilliant blue: This dye is used in retinal surgeries to stain the internal limiting membrane (ILM), aiding in ILM peeling during macular hole surgeries. It is not used for lens capsule staining.

 

Option D. Rose Bengal: This dye stains dead or devitalized cells and is used in the diagnosis of conditions like dry eye syndrome. It is not used for staining the anterior capsule of the lens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trypan blue dye is used for staining the anterior capsule of the lens during cataract surgery to aid in the creation of a continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis.
